awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Secure and Privacy-assured Data Service Outsourcing in Cloud Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The economics of Cloud Computing Cloud Computing impels a fundamental shift in how data services are deployed and delivered, enabling flexible, dynamic outsourcing while reducing capital cost commitments for hardware and software. However, cloud computing also deprives customers of direct control over the systems that manage their data, raising security and privacy concerns. This research develops the means to provide secure and privacy-assured data service outsourcing that is usable, scalable, and meets performance goals, through: (1) an encrypted cloud data service, including fuzzy and ranked keyword search with strong privacy-assurance for large numbers of users and files,  (2) scalable and owner-controlled cloud data sharing service with fine-grained data access enforcement and scalability, and (3) privacy-preserving secure cloud storage auditing that maintains strong guarantees of storage correctness.
Enabling secure and privacy-assured data service outsourcing is fundamental to the success of cloud computing deployment. This project also develops curricula and teaches and supervises students.  Materials of this project will be made available online as tutorials, software packages, and publications of general interest.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on deploying the most fundamental data services including data utilization,data sharing, and data storage on the commercial public cloud, with built-in security and privacyassurance as well as high level data service performance, system usability, and scalability.This outcome report summarizes the major research and education activities and findings for the performance period from August 1, 2011 to July 31, 2018.

Our first research module tackles secure and dependable cloud storage auditing. We have made important progress on the problem of how to outsource storage service in cloud while maintaining strong storage correctness guarantee. With storage outsourcing, data are no longer locally possessed by the data owners. As a result, traditional cryptographic primitives for the purpose of storage correctness protection cannot be directly utilized. This is because they usually require local copy of data for the integrity verification, which is not viable when storage is outsourced into the cloud. Besides, the large amount and dynamic nature of cloud data as well as owner’s constrained computing capabilities further makes the task of data correctness auditing in a cloud environment expensive and even formidable. To address these challenges, we propose to explore efficient storage auditing designs with public auditability and data dynamic support. We first investigate a public-key based homomorphic linear authenticator (HLA) technique to assist our random-sampling based auditing design. We then propose to investigate a novel sequence-enforced Merkle Hash Tree structure and seamlessly employ it with an improved HLA construction to support efficient yet provable updates to outsourced data, since cloud data can be changing under different application context. In order to reduce the tedious computation/communication overhead on TPA when the number of data auditing delegation grows into a large scale, we also investigate how to enable TPA to aggregate all these auditing tasks into a single one and verify it in a batch manner, i.e., simultaneously. We also extend the scenario to the case of distributed storage and investigate storage auditing with fault localization and data recovery and make important progress on the problem of how to outsource storage service in cloud while maintaining strong storage correctness guarantee. Finally, our research that focuses on cloud storage auditing with verifiable outsourcing of key updates brings the key-exposure resistance, an important feature especially desirable to error-prone clients, to the problem domain.

Our second research module is privacy-assured and effective cloud data utilization. We study the problem on how to achieve an encrypted cloud data utilization service with strong privacy assurance, while enjoying high service-level performance inherently demanded by the large number of data users and huge amount data files. As textual information is ubiquitous in data management systems, many cloud applications have an increasing need to support similarity keyword searches on outsourced data collections. Thus, we focus on a very challenging problem of privacy-assured similarity keyword search, which, opposing to exact keyword match, aims for the discovery of similar keywords with respect to a given distance measure and greatly enhances system usability and user searching experience. To address the challenges, we first develop a series of suppressing techniques to build storage-efficient similarity keyword set. Based on that, we then investigate different secure indexing techniques to establish a privacy-assured and usable fuzzy keyword search design over encrypted cloud data. In order to further enrich the spectrum of secure cloud data utilization services, we also study how the notion of similarity search naturally supports the notion of fuzzy search and vice versa. Here fuzzy search is a previously studied notion aiming only to tolerate typos and representation inconsistencies in the user searching input. Furthermore, We study the problem on how to achieve an encrypted cloud data utilization service with strong privacy-assurance, while enjoying high service-level performance inherently demanded by the large number of data users and huge amount data files, including image datasets and the related applications.

Our third research module is scalable and owner-controlled cloud data sharing, which explores owner-controlled cloud data sharing service that achieves fine-grained data access enforcement and meanwhile system scalability, given the challenging that data no longer resides on owners' trusted domain. we have particularly addressed the major challenges of high overhead in various aspects when using Attribute-based Encryption (ABE) crypto systems to enforce access control in realistic contexts, and the major challenges of privacy protection in various aspects when using differential privacy to enforce privacy guarantees in realistic contexts.
